document.title: New York State Next Generation English Language Arts Learning Standards

0459780B4A1B42A5B3CBC49165F90E48.description: Use an apostrophe to form contractions and frequently occurring possessives.

F37B371EA8F34926A1B1FBCD611B150C.description: Use commas in greetings and closings of letters.

654BA00C29D34A009C4C0456262F6D4A.description: Use commas in dates and to separate single words in a series.

614867AFDD344CE4ADDEAFDAA55613E8.description: Capitalize dates and names of people.

0BEC368C9DAC447BA05731180EA6510D.description: Capitalize the first word in a sentence and the pronoun I.

CF36A06C89B94B7B981EB5CBCDE5F323.description: Capitalize the first letter of their name.

9A62D016FE5D42F989C9985D0C7F4E73.description: Consult reference materials as needed to check and correct spellings.

8EA881FC80DB482386E7E403AEE802FE.description: Write a letter or letters for most consonant and short-vowel sounds (phonemes).

F6ED447CFFF64556B5FC1EE2C9EFDDD4.description: Generalize learned spelling patterns when writing words (e.g., cage → rage; boy → toy).

06EFF0D752AE4F59A236C06075302B67.description: Use conventional spelling for words with common spelling patterns and for frequently occurring irregular words.

5B9CBAC3CD114CBF870B06F495AC599E.description: Spell unknown words phonetically, drawing on phonemic awareness and spelling conventions.

4E517DBB56DF437A958D260600A5396D.description: Spell simple words phonetically, drawing on knowledge of sound-letter relationships.

18BE1B4C9D424D148E30AB69AE15349B.description: Attempt to write symbols or letters to represent words.

23E505A6DEE44799B8587034FCF5C4A9.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of academic English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

A4D54FF16AC148799F0DCB13AD3A964F.description: Understand and use simple and compound sentences in speech or writing (e.g., The child read the book; The child read the book, but she did not watch the movie).

D7D324A6F0A144A59699A223B056C3A1.description: Use frequently occurring transition words (e.g., first, then, therefore, finally)

1B8967F3DA974CB2B2BDBF9FB5E88C96.description: Use frequently occurring conjunctions (e.g., and, but, or, so because).

E5BDA2A45D7D4CB485BD629F59104B7C.description: Form and use the past tense of frequently occurring irregular verbs (e.g., sat, hid, told).

2829A3A93FAC437099ACFBDF906CE983.description: Use verbs to convey a sense of past, present, and future (e.g., Yesterday I walked home; Today I walk home; Tomorrow I will walk home).

38360DB265FF4C518FCC38DA38742A6F.description: Use personal, possessive, and indefinite pronouns (e.g., I, me, my; they, them, their, anyone, everything).

6ACE82D8C45E495180D6D472F2E450E1.description: Produce and expand complete sentences in shared language activities.

353F514BF0D44E3AB1CFAB5B383F55DC.description: Use frequently occurring prepositions (e.g., to, from, in, out, on, off, for, of, by, with).

E30EF7D5E96141F7BC46232605B7B732.description: Understand and use interrogatives (question words—e.g., who, what, where, when, why, how).

A4F6FFCF681B4987950EAD64FDC69A00.description: Use singular and plural nouns with matching verbs in basic sentences (e.g., The boy jumps; The boys jump).

E1FDA74100414771A0B1259ECC1A04B2.description: Form and use frequently occurring irregular plural nouns (e.g., feet, children, mice, fish).

33E3F4B539F8441DA66E2423B731F4D1.description: Form and use regular plural nouns (e.g., dog, dogs; wish, wishes).

94AD1275863349E599E14B2E636802D4.description: Use common, proper, and possessive nouns.

345C614CD89145A2820F6D552D7F6D58.description: Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.

F80938BDEC7A46C19AFF136FCC852D37.description: Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs (orally)

270802C9BDBA447F80164C875D294F77.description: Print all upper- and lowercase letters.

A7F718559C2A45C6BA07BA323A7C39AE.description: Print many upper- and lowercase letters

2D282426C68749FAA2A9F341BD7C8223.description: Print upper- and lowercase letters in their name

0B948D9BE4E64565802FC5FDDC1ECC6F.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of academic English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

32CE7CEE30AB4CFF8440B7C11FFD85DE.description: Conventions of Academic English/Language for Learning

8502D919E76145E8889889A566C258D0.description: Use words and phrases acquired through language rich experiences, conversations, reading and being read to, responding to texts, and child-centered, play-based experiences.

D668A4E4F0FB41D4A600B383505F6621.description: Use words to identify and describe the world around them.

AA08DFFD81D64C8C97C70F9246A34267.description: Demonstrate understanding of frequently occurring words by relating them to their opposites (e.g., hot/cold).

8730A34A463E4480B514133D5C7AA4EE.description: Sort common objects into categories (e.g., shapes, foods) for understanding of the concepts the categories represent.

1CD45F69BBCE465697619DEB7DF1C25C.description: Explore and discuss word relationships and word meanings.

1AA237ED5F184744869299ACFD5F8118.description: Explore and use new vocabulary in child-centered, authentic, play-based experiences.

C729B8870E864F39A41DD6C5B08C246B.description: Describe familiar people, places, things, and events.

DFEB6308B29E44C0BB4EB5F46FB51D1E.description: Interact with diverse formats and texts.

F57EC9620F53494DAEA6EF52D6683571.description: Consider individual differences when communicating with others.

253150B7B96545BF99885E9387803077.description: Participate in conversations through multiple exchanges.

A40342D936AC421284FA5040156C2945.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions, including listening to others, taking turns, and staying on topic.

D954BC64EE68499D85A913B6B7272075.description: Participate in collaborative conversations with diverse peers and adults in small and large groups and during play.

20ACA43C005348A2A3D258DFFB23D9AB.description: Engage in a discussion using gathered information from experiences or provided resources.

B167B5FA0D0D4C7F99EE7FC9DE8DD16C.description: Develop questions and participate in shared research and exploration to answer questions and to build and share knowledge.

0F98431CC4854481AEE4A48F352585C8.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

8C850B77F9BE46968A26252AB7A6C1E7.description: Create a response to a text, author, or personal experience (e.g., dramatization, art work, or poem).

6EC136EB242C4FC68F9EB69A8E359C52.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, oral expression, and/or emergent writing to narrate an event or events in a sequence.

AFC9B632446E4587A1E6418010188BCB.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, oral expression, and/or emergent writing to name a familiar topic and supply information in child-centered, authentic, play-based learning.

5F1C43A24BB54102A7A0531CF6F341D1.description: Use a combination of drawing, dictating, oral expression, and/or emergent writing to state an opinion about a familiar topic in child-centered, authentic, play-based learning.

DA3C7E0487924868AE4AC1F9B88ABEC7.description: Displays emergent reading behaviors with purpose and understanding.

AFE548DB52CE485280518E205AFE268D.description: Demonstrate one-to-one letter-sound correspondence by producing the primary sound of some consonants.

0D8C36B364B94859BCB59B50B7E17E1C.description: Demonstrate emergent phonics and word analysis skills.

9FE4D66AF8184D0E820184CD1B0CF590.description: Isolate and pronounce the initial sounds (phonemes) in spoken one-syllable words (e.g. the /m/ in map).

581BCC0162494083A18687D55C19A6F8.description: Begin to recognize individual syllables within spoken words (e.g. cup cake, base ball).

0A039F13C5C34800AA3C748D717A732D.description: Begin to recognize and match spoken words that rhyme (e.g. songs, chants, finger plays).

CE2581D044AB46BDB6394740ED3C722A.description: Demonstrate an emerging understanding of spoken words, syllables, and sounds (phonemes).

37ADD119C12A4E0495B595868ED1644A.description: Differentiate letters from numerals. PKRF1g: Identify front cover and back cover.

4DCAD3FFCC084CD8ABB5CED431BEA15B.description: Recognize that letters are grouped to form words.

9425136FD7CF4286AB0CA3FE890DA030.description: Recognize and name some upper/lowercase letters of the alphabet, especially those in own name.

929320C039554F47AD1A59F63F02CE71.description: Understand that words are separated by spaces in print.

0D91BB1F77BA438286E8394770C3FEBD.description: Recognize that spoken words are represented in written language.

EBCE0BD3C06241BD9A2934E58CB69A93.description: Recognize that words are read from left to right, top to bottom, and page to page.

79D7CBF8FF1643D7A8C4DD961D4A9B42.description: Demonstrate understanding of the organization and basic features of print.

ABFA4AE0CF3647E58A2F4863BE069113.description: Make connections between self, text, and the world.

E3CDC10489634C26A1180EEFDDD50B22.description: Describe the relationship between illustrations and the text.

C1B2E2CCC7C54A009434DD77E25DF3E8.description: Describe the role of an author and illustrator.

8BAC53EF88DF4EF09A64323F42050261.description: Interact with a variety of genres.

6CE836F3C77647068CB15C25E642E04F.description: Exhibit an interest in learning new vocabulary.

91B780407B164F46AAE7621F8E6A2C96.description: Develop and answer questions about characters, major events, and pieces of information in a text.

C655B5B2AB154225897B7B5773F1B32C.description: Retell stories or share information from a text.

9C0056895819470C835D5097974C433C.description: Participate in discussions about a text.
